close_symbols: commit fields used (off, block, ptag, crc, begin)
explanation:
For assessing whether any operations in lfs_dir_commitcrc are dead (i.e. could be removed without changing observable behaviour) we must know the types, macros, constants and the semantics / side-effects of called functions and the fields read/written by this function. The listed symbols are necessary for that analysis:

- lfs_t: contains device, cache and config pointers; needed to know whether writes/reads have side effects and how cfg influences control flow.
- struct lfs_commit: exact layout (off, block, ptag, crc, begin) and which fields are persisted/observed outside the function to decide whether assignments are observable.
- lfs->cfg (block_size, prog_size, cache_size): these config values control branches (end calculation, fcrc decision, flush threshold); removing code might change timing/placement so they are required to determine observability.
- lfs_off_t: underlying integer type (signed/unsigned/size) affects arithmetic and comparisons that determine which branches execute.
- lfs_tag_t: tag width/representation affects tag construction, XORs and stored bytes — important to know whether writes change on-disk state.
- struct lfs_fcrc: layout and size are needed to know what lfs_dir_commitattr will write and whether that write is observable.
- LFS_MKTAG, LFS_TYPE_FCRC, LFS_TYPE_CCRC: macros/constants used to construct tags; required to determine exact bits written and whether those writes are meaningful.
- LFS_ERR_CORRUPT: error code returned when CRC checks fail; needed to assess control-flow/return behaviour and whether CRC checks are necessary.
- LFS_MULTIVERSION: conditional compilation macro that gates writing of fcrc; necessary to know if that code path is ever compiled in (dead vs. compiled-out code distinction).
- lfs_fs_disk_version: determines runtime decision under LFS_MULTIVERSION; needed to see if the fcrc branch can execute at runtime.
- lfs_alignup and lfs_min: arithmetic helpers used to compute 'end' and noff; must be known to decide which loops/branches run and whether related writes are reachable/necessary.
- lfs_bd_read: reads from block device / cache — its side-effects (cache population, error codes including LFS_ERR_CORRUPT) influence whether the preceding read and its byte (eperturb) are needed.
- lfs_bd_crc: computes CRCs over device data; its behaviour determines whether the subsequent CRC checks are meaningful and thus whether the writes they verify are necessary.
- lfs_bd_prog: programs (writes) data to the block device; crucial to know whether those writes are observable externally (persistence) and thus not dead.
- lfs_bd_sync: flush/sync semantics (and whether it has side-effects beyond blocking) are needed to judge whether the explicit sync calls are necessary.
- lfs_dir_commitattr: performs attribute (fcrc) commits; its side-effects (additional on-disk writes, updates to commit state) determine if the call is required.
- lfs_crc: pure CRC update function semantics determine whether updating commit->crc and writing CRC tags is meaningful.
- lfs_tobe32 / lfs_tole32 / lfs_fcrc_tole32: endian conversion functions alter bytes written to disk; required to know exact on-disk representation and whether conversions are no-ops on some platforms (which would affect dead-code assessment).
- pcache/rcache (type and field .off): the caching structures and pcache.off are read to decide when to flush; knowledge of their semantics (and whether reading them has side-effects) is necessary to determine if flush logic is dead.
- commit fields used (off, block, ptag, crc, begin): explicit mention to emphasize that all reads/writes to these fields must be considered observable (or not) when deciding if an assignment or write is dead.

In short, these symbols provide: (1) the structural/representation context to know exactly what bytes are written, (2) the runtime conditions and side-effects of I/O and CRC calls that make operations externally observable, and (3) the compile-time/runtime guards that can render code unreachable or effectively dead. Without them you cannot determine whether a write/assignment is removable without changing program behaviour.
